body: Release build failed due to a glitch in obtaining Java artifacts. Will retest.
@sbroeder, could you take a look at these changes (especially the stuff I put into the DTM files)?

@DaveBirdsall 
Thanks for your detailed explanations!
Yes I should have used uppercase for acronyms. God is in the details. :)
Your comment has been incorporated.

@DaveBirdsall 
Thanks for your detailed explanations! Your comment has been incorporated. :)

- ISO88591
I've checked and corrected ISO8859-1 to ISO88591, since the occurrences of the latter are more than that of the former.

- UTF-8
All cases are UTF8 except the following one: 
> UTF8 (UTF-8) is a variable-length (1 to 4 bytes) encoding of Unicode characters including those in supplementary planes. It is compatible with the US-ASCII character set.

This is an appropriate usage, so no changes have been made on this.

@sbroeder and @selvaganesang, I've pushed a rework. In the coprocessor, I tried adding a scanner.close(), but it turns out the close() API is not available for HFileInterface until HBase 2.0. So I put a comment there for now. In HBaseClient.java, I replaced the use of the deprecated HConnection with the more current Connection, as you suggested Selva.

this change is try to fix int type not check boundary which given by client, so the emphasis is in TrafT4PreparedStatement.java, check Integer Boundary when type is INTEGER (sign), and check Unsigned Integer Boundary when type is INTEGER UNSIGNED.
and The error message is try to let the users know what's the value they given in the request, this will help users quickly locate the issues
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/2013/
@selvaganesang, even with all the statement and connection closes that @xwq has added, the JDBC tests still fail hitting statement limits. Any ideas on why that might be?
The test failure is in the JDBC suite; it is a problem with nowait statement depth. It is not related to these changes.
The test failure is due to a nowait statement limit problem in the JDBC tests. This particular change is not the cause of that. I am merging this change in spite of the failure.
The test failure is due to a nowait statement limit problem in the JDBC tests. This particular change is not the cause of that. I am merging this change in spite of the failure.
You can run with ABORT_ON_ERROR=2026 and get the dump of the process that returns this error. This would help to debug this issue further
I am running in my environment to reproduce this problem

There were around 13 statements in OPEN or FETCH statement with the source string
"select dataOffset, chunkLen, stringParam from table(ghost table \"TRAFODION\".\"T4QA\".\"LOBDescChunks__08574991311373262837_0002\") where descPartnKey = <val1> and descSyskey = <val2>"

These internal statements should be closed for the jdbc_test_cdh to pass or comment out the tests that triggers these internal statements for time being.

Changing the application wouldn't help
It is strange how these tests were enabled without going through the check-PR jobs. Check-PR jobs should have failed in the PR that enabled these tests

+1. 

Without this fix, sometimes, ODBC will send wrong message to DCS in multi threads.
I am merging this PR in though check-PR failed. The failure in jdbc_test-cdh is being worked on

Interestingly, Trafodion T4 driver uses WeakReference to close the statements even when the application fails to close  the statement but the statement is gc-ed by JVM. See TrafT4Connection.gcStmts and WeakReference objects/Queues in TrafT4Statement.java.  For the statements to be gc-ed, it is important to use a small new object heap in JVM. I undestand from @arvind-narain that the jdbc tests scripts are run within the maven. I would suggest that maven is started with appropriate max heap size rather than the default . The default would be 1/4 of the physical memory of the jenkins VM.
I will merge this change in. Check-PR failed in jdbc_test-cdh which is a known failure

Let me rework this a bit so it is explicitly clear as to where we are closing the internal cursor on the descriptor table. Will make it more readable and easier to maintain.  Please don't merge yet.

The tests also have to be modified so the DDL gets created consistently. Here re the findings ..
------------------------------
From: Arvind Narain 
Sent: Tuesday, August 22, 2017 10:00 PM
To: Sandhya Sundaresan <sandhya.sundaresan@esgyn.com>; Weiqing <weiqing.xu@esgyn.cn>
Cc: Selva Govindarajan <selva.govindarajan@esgyn.com>; Kevin <kaihua.xu@esgyn.cn>
Subject: RE: JDBC test failures on official run having to do with DDL

I looked up a little bit more. With mvn since there is no order in which the tests get picked up, the success/failure depends on which test is executed before TestBlob.

Jdbc tests seem to utilize three different ways of setting up each test suite. 

One way is to use Utils to setup the connection. Here if the schema does not exist, then it gets created.

Another way is to have BeforeClass methods that setup connection and the schema, tables needed. AfterClass goes aheads and cleans the tables and sometimes the schema  this is what happens when BatchTest is run.

Third is what TestBlob is doing  using DriverManager.GetConnection to setup the connection. Here schema doesnt get created. Hence if the expected schema has been dropped by the previous test suite (BatchTest) then the test fails since it cannot create the tables. 

So yes, tests need to be looked at again so that DriverManager.GetConnection call is replaced in TestBlob*,TestClob*,TestGetIndexInfo*.
test failed seems caused by hive issue, not by the driver.  I close it to fix the similar issue on WCHAR.
